newsitem.title: USA: Arco finds oil in Alaska's Tarn prospect.
newsitem.headline: Arco finds oil in Alaska's Tarn prospect.

text.p: ARCO Alaska Inc and BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc said Monday they found oil at Tarn Prospect on Alaska's North Slope and agreed to jointly develop Kuparuk, Alaska's second-largest oil field.
The oil has been found in two delineation wells and a sidetrack in the Tarn prospect west of the Kuparuk River Field.

Tests at the Tarn 2 well yielded a steady, stimulated flow rate in excess of 2,000 barrels-per-day (bpd) of 38-degree API gravity oil from a sandstone reservoir discovered at a depth of 5,200 feet. Tarn 2 is the first well drilled in this year's three-well Tarn exploration program, the companies said.
The companies said they are assessing Tarn for potential reserves, and a third delineation well is expected to be completed this month.
The companies also signed an agreement to explore and appraise a 580- square-mile area that includes the ARCO-operated Kuparuk River Unit and adjacent acreage.
The pact allows production of satellite oil fields through current Kuparuk processing sites and clears the way for developement of West Sak, a heavy oil field.
ARCO Alaska holds 58.5 percent of Tarn Prospect. BP Exploration holds a 41.5 percent interest.
"The agreement establishes a new, more cooperative way of doing business on the North Slope," said Richard Campbell, president of BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc.
"It will accelerate resource development, provide opportunities for Alaskans and enhance state revenues," he said
Joint exploration drilling during 1997 may include two prospects in addition to Tarn -- Cache and Tabasco.
The joint exploration of Kuparuk has identified more than 10 satellite prospects -- including the West Sak heavy oil accumulation -- which could yield potential reserves of almost 1 billion barrels.
